lines.text: Jim... how do you uh... how do you evaluate... the oxygen situation?

Um... Well, we have whatever oxygen's left in the spacecraft system. And, there are only, uh... two bottles of emergency oxygen on board, five minutes each, that's uh... ten man-minutes. Um... my backpack, and uh... Lloyd's and Stone's, but um... there's not much oxygen left in them.
Well, you'll have to save your backpacks for the EVA transfer
Yeah I know that.
[pause]
55 minutes,
[longer pause]
we'll be dead by then.
Well, only if you... continue to use oxygen at the present rate...
Well, uh, we can't cut down.
Let's... think about that...
Do, uh... do you want us to lower the partial pressure again?
No, we've examined that, it won't work...
Well we're lyin' here like corpses now... uh... what else can we do?
You must... think...
[astronauts exchange glances, realizing the unspoken implication of Keith's statement]
Yeah, we're... thinkin'...
Are we talking about the same thing?
Yeah.
Why don't you... talk it over. If you could... work out something... it would be of great help...
Yeah we'll talk it over.
I must point out Jim, that any *effective* action must be taken immediately...
Look, don't tell me what to do! We've been takin' your god damned orders and where the hell are we? From now on WE'RE gonna make all the decisions! Whatever we do, you're OUT OF IT!
Oh I uh... appreciate what you're saying Jim... and I agree with you... You're exactly right...
06, the crew will be dead. There's not enough oxygen left for three men to live that long.
Well what about... two men?
We don't figure that way, we plot total pressure against total use.
Is there sufficient oxygen for two men? For one?

[long pause]
Two might just make it.
Jesus, fifty-five minutes... We'll be pretty cold by then.
Well, one of us's gonna have to go. I mean uh... that's what we're talkin' about, isnt it? One of us goes and the... other two stay. What... what are we gonna do?
two big guys throw the little guy out, okay?
[Keith is pulled over by the Highway Patrol for speeding]
Look, I've got to get to a telephone!
Will you shut off your engine please?
Officer, I'm Charles Keith, head of Manned Space!
I know who you are. You have no brake lights. Your license is expired. You may be able to get to the moon, but mister you're a menace on the highway!

[after being asked by Stone what he saw when a psychologist held up a blank sheet of paper during his astronaut acceptance boards]
I saw a field covered with snow. And underneath was new oats. Then the snow melted and the field turned to green. But the psychologist said I was all wrong, it was just a blank sheet of paper.
He took you anyway?
Yeah, I guess they made a mistake.
No, no, they don't make mistakes.
That's right, I forgot. They don't make mistakes do they?
[the entire crew begins to laugh at the irony]
Okay Buzz you're right. To hell with waiting for a bunch of slide-rule jockeys. We used to fix the airplanes we flew with paperclips. Lets get into our hard suits and fix this bird.

[smiling]
Okay Jimmy.
Listen, all you guys gotta worry about is where you want me to set you down after I make the transfer. Go on, pick your spot. Edwards? Vegas? How about the beach at Malibu?

[attempting to contact the Apollo capsule, which has the call-sign "Ironman One"]
Ironman, this is Keith. Ironman, this is Keith! Do you read me?

[He's disconnected his oxygen hose and transferred it to Buzz. Now breathing only cabin air, which is very thin, he's becoming delirious due to lack of oxygen, and starts to ramble]
Purpose... and objective...

[with more insistence]
Ironman One, this is Keith. Do you read!
Purpose and objective.
Ironman, this is Keith. Do you read me?

[starts to giggle]
Purpose... the acquisition of... of... data!

[sounding more impatient]
Ironman, do you read me?

[starts looking out the cabin window, sees the silhouette of the Russian Voskhod capsule approaching]
No! Oh, God. Oh, God. How... beautiful.
I'm beginning to see... visions...
Stoney, come in!
...of death. There you are...
